name: Mountain Pose
precaution: If you have any lower back or neck issues, be sure to keep your spine in alignment by gently engaging your core muscles to prevent overarching. Avoid locking your knees, and instead, keep them slightly soft to prevent hyperextension. As with any yoga pose, listen to your body, and if you experience discomfort or pain, ease out of the pose and consult a healthcare provider if needed.
source: Mackenzie, Susi. Yoga Anatomy. 2nd ed., Human Kinetics, 2018, pp. 52-55.

name: Hero Pose
precaution: Those with knee, ankle, or hip injuries should avoid this posture or modify it, as sitting directly on the heels can strain these areas. It’s crucial to keep the knees together and aligned, not allowing them to splay outward, to avoid stress on the joints. Individuals with tight quadriceps or limited flexibility should ease into the pose slowly, perhaps with props for support, to avoid overstretching the muscles.
source: Tirumalai Krishnamacharya. Yoga Makaranda. Translated by A.G. Mohan, Integral Yoga Publications, 2000, pp. 101-103.

name: Lotus Pose
precaution: This pose requires significant flexibility in the hips, knees, and ankles, so those with knee or ankle injuries, or those experiencing discomfort in these areas, should avoid it or practice with modifications. Sitting in full Lotus Pose can place excessive pressure on the knees, so it’s important to ensure that the knees are not forced down too far, as this could lead to strain or injury. If you feel any discomfort in the knees, it’s recommended to use props, such as cushions or blocks, to elevate the hips, which can help reduce tension and provide a more accessible version of the pose. Additionally, it’s important to maintain proper alignment in the spine, ensuring that the back remains straight and the chest is open, to avoid unnecessary strain on the lower back.

name: Staff Pose
precaution: Individuals with lower back, hip, or knee issues should be mindful in Staff Pose, as improper alignment can aggravate these areas. It’s important to engage the core and maintain a tall spine, avoiding slouching or collapsing the chest. Those with tight hamstrings or calves may find it challenging to keep the legs fully extended and straight; using props like a cushion under the hips can help. Practitioners should also be cautious if they have any pelvic imbalances, as the pose requires sitting upright with both legs extended forward.

name: Table Top Pose
precaution: Individuals with wrist injuries or discomfort should be cautious, as the pose requires weight-bearing on the wrists. Modifying the pose by using props like wrist supports or performing it on fists instead of the palms can help reduce strain. Those with shoulder or back issues should focus on maintaining proper alignment by ensuring that the shoulders are directly over the wrists and the hips are aligned over the knees. Engaging the core muscles helps to prevent sagging in the lower back, which could lead to discomfort or injury.

name: Cat Pose
precaution: Individuals with neck injuries should avoid straining their neck by ensuring that the head moves in alignment with the spine rather than dropping or craning it. It's important to keep the spine neutral and avoid over-arching the back, as this could exacerbate lower back discomfort or pain. People with wrist issues should modify the pose by using fists instead of palms or placing a cushion under the wrists for added support.

name: Cow Pose
precaution: It's important to avoid over-arching the lower back, as this can put undue pressure on the spine and cause discomfort, especially for individuals with lower back issues. Those with neck injuries should ensure that the head is in a neutral position, avoiding excessive tilting or craning. People with wrist problems should modify the pose by using fists instead of flat palms, or placing padding under the wrists for added support.

name: Child's Pose
precaution: While Child's Pose (Balasana) is generally a gentle and restorative pose, there are some precautions to keep in mind to ensure a safe and effective practice. If you have knee injuries or discomfort, you may want to place a cushion or blanket under your knees for added support and cushioning. For those with lower back pain, it is important to avoid collapsing the lower back or forcing the torso down too far; instead, focus on gently lengthening the spine while keeping the hips aligned over the knees. If you are pregnant, especially in later stages, it's advised to modify the pose by keeping the knees slightly apart to avoid pressure on the belly or chest.

name: Puppy Pose
precaution: Those with shoulder injuries or discomfort should avoid overextending the arms or putting excessive strain on the shoulders. Similarly, individuals with lower back issues should ensure their spine remains supported and avoid collapsing into the pose, as this could exacerbate tension or pain. People with sensitive knees may benefit from using a blanket or cushion for added padding under the knees to prevent discomfort. Pregnant practitioners, especially in the later stages, should modify the pose to avoid compressing the belly.

name: Tree Pose
precaution: Those with ankle, knee, or hip injuries should be careful, as placing weight on one leg and balancing can put strain on these areas. People with balance issues or a history of vertigo may find it difficult to hold the pose, and they may need to modify or avoid it to prevent falls. Additionally, individuals with lower back problems should be cautious when trying to keep the spine straight and avoid overextending or arching the back. Pregnant individuals or those in their second or third trimesters may find it challenging to maintain the pose due to changes in balance and body alignment, so modifications may be helpful.

name: Bound Angle Pose
precaution: Those with knee injuries or knee pain should be careful, as the position of the knees pressing towards the floor can exacerbate discomfort or strain. People with hip injuries or limited hip flexibility may also find this pose challenging, as it requires significant hip opening. Pregnant individuals should avoid deep forward folds and may opt for a more supportive variation of the pose, focusing on opening the hips without going too deep into the stretch.

name: Supine Spinal Twist Pose
precaution: Those with spinal injuries, such as herniated discs or any serious back issues, should avoid this pose or consult a healthcare provider before attempting it, as the twisting motion can exacerbate discomfort. Pregnant individuals should also avoid deep twists, particularly after the first trimester, to protect the baby and avoid placing undue pressure on the abdomen. Additionally, people with hip or knee injuries should modify the posture by keeping the legs in a less intense position to prevent strain. It's also important to perform the twist gently and within your range of motion, ensuring that the neck and shoulders remain relaxed throughout the pose to avoid strain.

name: Happy Baby Pose
precaution: Those with knee or hip injuries should be mindful, as the deep opening of the hips and the pressure placed on the knees can exacerbate discomfort. People with sensitive knees may consider using props, such as placing a cushion or blanket beneath the knees for support to alleviate strain. Similarly, individuals with lower back issues, particularly those with herniated discs or sciatica, should avoid pulling too forcefully on the feet, as this could place additional pressure on the spine. Pregnant individuals or those in their second or third trimester should also be cautious, as deep stretches of the hips and lower back may place unnecessary pressure on the abdomen.

name: Corpse Pose
precaution: People with back injuries or chronic back pain may find it uncomfortable to lie flat on their back, as it can exacerbate spinal discomfort. Individuals with severe neck issues should also be mindful, ensuring that their head is properly supported on the mat, or using a rolled towel or cushion under the neck for added support.

name: Plank Pose
precaution: If you have wrist or shoulder injuries, such as carpal tunnel syndrome, tendonitis, or rotator cuff issues, you should approach Plank Pose with caution, as the weight-bearing nature of the pose can aggravate these conditions. If you experience lower back pain, ensure your core is properly engaged and your alignment is correct to avoid sagging in the lower back, which could worsen discomfort. Pregnant individuals, especially in the later stages, should avoid Plank Pose due to the pressure it places on the abdomen and lower back, and instead consider gentler alternatives like a wall plank.

name: Four-Limbed Staff Pose
precaution: Beginners or those new to yoga should be mindful of their form to avoid straining the shoulders, wrists, and lower back. People with wrist issues, such as carpal tunnel syndrome or wrist pain, should modify the pose or avoid it until strength and flexibility improve. Those with shoulder injuries or limited shoulder mobility should also be cautious, as the pose requires significant shoulder stability and strength to prevent strain. Similarly, individuals with lower back pain or a history of spinal issues should avoid letting the hips sag, as this can lead to discomfort or injury. Pregnant individuals should consult with a healthcare provider before practicing this pose, as the core engagement and pressure on the abdomen may not be suitable.

name: Upward-Facing Dog
precaution: Those with lower back issues should be cautious, as overextending the lower back can lead to strain. It’s important to engage the core muscles and lift the chest rather than collapsing in the lower back. Individuals with wrist sensitivity should be mindful of the pressure on the wrists in this pose. For those with shoulder injuries or limited flexibility, it’s crucial to avoid collapsing the shoulders forward. Keep the shoulders away from the ears, draw the shoulder blades down, and ensure the elbows are not locked. Additionally, maintaining proper neck alignment is essential to prevent strain—avoid craning the neck backward too far and keep it in a neutral position. Pregnant individuals, especially in later stages, should avoid this pose due to the pressure it places on the abdomen and lower back. It is also important for those with spinal conditions, such as herniated discs or scoliosis, to consult a healthcare provider before attempting the pose.

name: Downward-Facing Dog
precaution: Individuals with wrist issues should avoid excessive weight on the wrists, ensuring the fingers are spread wide and the weight is distributed evenly across the palms. For those with shoulder concerns, the shoulders should be engaged by pressing the shoulder blades down the back to prevent any unnecessary strain. The neck should remain in a neutral position, with the gaze directed between the legs or at the belly button. Avoid dropping or craning the neck, as this can cause tension in the cervical spine. Pregnant individuals should avoid Downward Dog, particularly after the first trimester, as the inversion may place pressure on the abdomen and disrupt circulation. People with pre-existing injuries to the back, neck, or shoulders should modify the pose.

name: Garland Pose
precaution: Those with knee injuries or chronic knee pain should avoid deep squatting or use props, such as a block under the hips, to reduce strain on the joints. People with hip or lower back issues, such as sciatica, should ease into the pose gently, ensuring that they maintain proper alignment to avoid exacerbating discomfort. Pregnant individuals may benefit from practicing a modified version with added support, like using a wall or yoga props, to avoid excessive pressure on the abdomen. Additionally, anyone with limited ankle mobility may find it challenging to keep their heels grounded and can use a rolled blanket under the heels for support.

name: Frog Pose
precaution: Individuals with knee, hip, or lower back injuries should approach the pose with caution or avoid it altogether, as the deep hip opening and pressure on the knees may exacerbate discomfort. If you have tight hips or hamstrings, it’s advisable to warm up thoroughly before attempting this posture to avoid overstretching. Make sure your knees are aligned with your toes and not collapsing inward, as improper alignment can strain the joints. If you experience any discomfort in the knees or hips, consider using props like a folded blanket under the knees or a bolster between the legs for additional support. Also, avoid forcing your chest down toward the floor—let your body move gradually into the stretch to prevent overextension.

name: Goddess Pose
precaution: People with knee issues, such as patellar tracking problems, knee arthritis, or injuries, should be mindful of the alignment of the knees in this pose. It’s important that the knees stay directly over the ankles and do not extend past the toes to avoid unnecessary strain on the joint. Those with lower back issues, particularly individuals with a history of herniated discs or sciatica, should be cautious about over-bending the knees or sinking too deeply into the squat, as this can cause strain on the lower back.  Additionally, those with hip or groin injuries should ensure that the external rotation of the hips is not too intense and that the pose is performed with care to avoid further injury.

name: Pyramid Pose
precaution: Individuals with tight hamstrings, lower back concerns, or a history of knee or hip injuries may want to approach Pyramid Pose with a bit more attention. If you have tight hamstrings, you might find it helpful to keep a slight bend in your front knee to avoid overstretching. For those with lower back discomfort, it’s important to maintain proper alignment by engaging your core and avoiding rounding your back during the forward fold. If you have knee issues, make sure your front knee stays aligned with your ankle, not extending too far forward. Similarly, if you have hip concerns, you may want to adjust the depth of the forward fold to ensure comfort.

name: Lizard Pose
precaution: Those with knee or hip injuries should avoid forcing the pose or practice with modifications to reduce pressure on these areas. In the lunge position, it’s important to ensure that the front knee does not extend beyond the toes, as this can strain the knee joint. Additionally, practitioners should avoid collapsing in the lower back; keeping the spine long and active helps to prevent excessive arching and discomfort. For those with tight hips, it may be helpful to practice with props like blocks or blankets under the hands or forearms to reduce the intensity of the stretch.

name: Low Lunge
precaution: Those with knee issues, particularly in the back knee, should be mindful of the pressure placed on the joint. It is important to avoid any discomfort by placing a cushion or blanket under the back knee for support. People with tight hips or limited flexibility in the hip flexors may find it challenging to fully lower the hips without straining, so they may need to use props or modify the pose by keeping the back knee slightly lifted or working on gentle hip-opening stretches beforehand. Additionally, individuals with lower back problems should engage their core and avoid overarching the lower back, as this can exacerbate pain or discomfort. Pregnant individuals should avoid placing too much pressure on the belly, and modify the pose.

name: Crescent High Lunge Pose
precaution: Those with knee issues, particularly in the front knee, should be mindful of their alignment, ensuring that the knee does not extend beyond the toes, which could strain the joint. People with lower back pain or a history of spinal injuries should avoid excessive arching of the lower back and focus on engaging the core to support the spine. Those with hip injuries or limited hip flexibility may find it difficult to sink deeply into the lunge without discomfort, so using props like blocks or modifying the depth of the pose can be beneficial. Pregnant individuals should avoid deep lunges and ensure that the hips are aligned properly to avoid strain on the pelvis.

name: Warrior I
precaution: Individuals with knee issues should be cautious when bending the front knee, ensuring it does not extend beyond the ankle to avoid unnecessary pressure on the joint. Those with hip or lower back pain should avoid forcing the hips to square completely forward, as this can cause discomfort or misalignment; instead, they can allow a slight external rotation of the back hip. For practitioners with shoulder injuries or limited mobility, the arms can be kept parallel to the ground or placed on the hips instead of being raised overhead.

name: Warrior II
precaution: If you have knee injuries, especially in the front knee, be cautious about allowing the knee to extend past the ankle, as this can put unnecessary strain on the joint. Those with tight hips or hamstrings should avoid overextending the legs and may need to reduce the depth of the lunge to prevent discomfort or injury. If you have lower back issues, it’s important to be mindful of your hip alignment, ensuring that your hips are open and facing to the side rather than forward, as improper alignment can strain the lower back. Individuals with shoulder problems should avoid lifting the shoulders up toward the ears and focus on relaxing them down to reduce tension. Pregnant individuals or those with balance concerns should modify the pose by shortening their stance or using props for additional support.

name: Warrior III
precaution: People with lower back injuries, such as herniated discs or sciatica, should approach Warrior III carefully, as it involves significant core and lower back engagement, which can aggravate pain if not performed with proper alignment. Likewise, individuals with knee or hip injuries should be mindful of not overstretching or hyperextending the joints during the pose, especially the standing leg. Pregnant individuals should also be cautious when performing Warrior III, particularly after the first trimester, as the deep forward bending and balancing may strain the core and affect stability. Those with shoulder injuries, such as rotator cuff issues, should avoid overextending the arms or straining the shoulders in the pose. Those with balance issues or dizziness, such as individuals prone to vertigo, should be cautious as this pose challenges coordination and could lead to falls.

name: Reverse Warrior
precaution: Individuals with knee injuries should avoid deeply bending the front knee to prevent strain on the joint. Individuals with lower back issues should also be cautious, as the pose involves deep hip flexion and a backbend, which may aggravate certain back conditions. Those with hip injuries or sacroiliac joint issues should avoid overextending or misaligning the pelvis during the pose. Pregnant individuals should modify the posture to ensure comfort and avoid any pressure on the abdomen, particularly in later stages of pregnancy. Lastly, individuals with shoulder injuries or limited shoulder mobility should be careful when reaching the arms overhead, as this movement can strain the shoulders if not performed with proper alignment.

name: Extended Side Angle
precaution: Those with knee, hip, or ankle injuries should modify the pose to avoid overstraining these areas, particularly by keeping the front knee aligned with the toes and not pushing it past the ankle. People with lower back issues should be cautious not to overextend or collapse into the lower back, as this can exacerbate discomfort; engaging the core and maintaining proper alignment is essential. Pregnant individuals should avoid deep twists and may need to adjust the stance for comfort, particularly in the later stages of pregnancy. Those with shoulder injuries should also be careful when extending the arms overhead or placing the hand on the floor, as this could strain the shoulder joints.

name: Triangle Pose
precaution: People with neck, back, or spinal issues, including herniated discs or scoliosis, should avoid overextending in the pose or twisting the neck too far, as this can exacerbate strain. Pregnant women should also be cautious, particularly in the later stages, as the wide leg stance may put pressure on the abdomen, and deep twisting could be uncomfortable. Individuals with hip injuries or tight hips may find the deep stretch in the groin and hip area challenging, and they may need to limit the depth of their stretch or use props to support their alignment. Those with knee injuries should ensure that their front knee is aligned properly and not pushing beyond the ankle to avoid added strain on the joint.

name: Half Moon Pose
precaution: Certain individuals should approach Half Moon Pose with caution or modify the pose to avoid strain or injury. Those with balance issues or recent ankle, knee, or hip injuries may find it challenging to stabilize the body in this pose and should take extra care, possibly using props like blocks for support. People with lower back problems should be cautious, as the pose requires a significant amount of core engagement and spinal alignment, which could exacerbate discomfort if not done properly. Additionally, individuals with neck issues should avoid looking up to the raised hand, as this can strain the neck—focusing on a fixed point on the floor or keeping the head neutral may be a better option. Pregnant individuals should also avoid the pose or modify it significantly to avoid strain on the abdomen and lower back.

name: Side Plank Pose
precaution: One of the primary precautions is to ensure proper alignment in the wrist, as the pose places weight on the hands. Avoid collapsing the wrist or overextending the arm; instead, press firmly into the floor with the fingers spread wide to distribute the weight evenly. For those with wrist injuries or discomfort, it’s recommended to practice the pose with the forearm on the ground instead of the hand. Additionally, be mindful of the shoulder joint by ensuring that the shoulder is stacked directly over the wrist, preventing strain in the shoulder. In the lifted position, it’s crucial to engage the core to protect the lower back from collapsing or over-arching. Practitioners should avoid letting the hips dip toward the floor, as this can lead to tension in the lower back. People with neck or back issues should modify the pose by keeping the head aligned with the body or by practicing with a variation that doesn’t require as much weight-bearing.

name: Upward Plank Pose
precaution: Those with wrist, shoulder, or neck injuries should be mindful of the pressure this pose places on these areas and may need to modify the pose or skip it entirely to avoid exacerbating the injury. Practitioners with lower back pain or tightness in the hamstrings and hip flexors may find this pose challenging and should move into it gradually, focusing on proper alignment and listening to their bodies. Pregnant individuals, especially in later stages, should avoid this pose due to the intense abdominal engagement and backbend.

name: Chair Pose
precaution: Those with knee issues or recent knee injuries should be careful when bending the knees deeply, as the pose places significant pressure on the knee joints. To protect the knees, it’s important to ensure that the knees are aligned with the toes and do not extend past the toes. Individuals with lower back pain should also be cautious, as the deep bend and engagement of the core muscles can place strain on the lumbar spine if proper alignment isn’t maintained. It’s important to keep the spine long and the chest lifted to avoid collapsing into the lower back. Those with hip issues or tight hips may find it difficult to maintain the deep squat position, and should focus on keeping the pelvis aligned and avoid any excessive arching of the lower back.  Additionally, individuals with shoulder or wrist injuries should avoid extending the arms overhead for prolonged periods, opting instead to keep the hands in a prayer position at the chest or on the hips.

name: Eagle Pose
precaution: Those with knee, ankle, or hip injuries should be careful, as the pose requires deep bending and twisting of the lower body, which can put strain on these areas. People with shoulder injuries may also need to modify the arm position, as the pose demands significant shoulder flexibility and strength when crossing the arms in front of the body. Those with lower back issues should avoid forcing the pose too deeply, especially the twist, and focus on engaging the core to support the spine. Pregnant individuals should avoid the deep twist and opt for a gentler variation, focusing on balance and stability without crossing the arms or legs too tightly.

name: Standing Forward Fold
precaution: It's important to engage the muscles of the legs, especially the quadriceps, to protect the knees and prevent hyperextension. Those with lower back issues should be cautious, as folding deeply can aggravate existing conditions; it's recommended to keep a slight bend in the knees to reduce pressure on the spine. It's also crucial to avoid forcing the fold too deep—progressing gently into the pose is key to maintaining a safe alignment. Pregnant individuals or those with neck issues should avoid letting the head hang freely, as this can put undue strain on the neck.

name: Wide-Legged Forward Fold
precaution: Those with lower back issues, such as herniated discs, sciatica, or chronic back pain, should be mindful of their spine's alignment and avoid overstraining the back in the forward bend. Similarly, individuals with tight hamstrings or hip flexors may experience discomfort if they force the stretch, so it's important to maintain a gentle approach and use props like blocks to support the torso. Pregnant individuals should avoid deep forward folds, particularly in the later stages of pregnancy, to protect the lower back and abdomen. Additionally, those with knee issues should be cautious and may need to slightly bend their knees to protect the joints and avoid strain.

name: Thread the Needle
precaution: Individuals with severe neck, shoulder, or spinal injuries should avoid the pose unless guided by a knowledgeable instructor. If there is mild discomfort in the neck, placing a yoga block or blanket under the head for support can help reduce strain. Those with tight hips or lower back issues may find it challenging to sit back into the pose fully, so it’s best to keep the hips slightly elevated. Pregnant practitioners or those with limited mobility should modify the pose to ensure comfort and safety.

name: Gate Pose
precaution: Individuals with knee, hip, or lower back issues should approach this pose with caution, as the side stretch and deep bend can put pressure on these areas. Ensure that the knee of the bent leg is aligned directly over the ankle to avoid straining the joint. Avoid collapsing the chest forward or rounding the spine; instead, maintain an elongated spine and engage the core to protect the lower back. If you have tight hips or hamstrings, do not push too deeply into the side stretch—practice a gentler version of the pose by keeping the torso more upright and gradually increasing flexibility over time. People with shoulder injuries should modify by keeping the arm extended to the side or using a prop for support rather than reaching the arm overhead.

name: Cobra Pose
precaution: Those with recent or chronic back injuries, particularly in the lower back or spine, should modify the pose or avoid it entirely to prevent aggravating pain. Practitioners with herniated discs or spinal stenosis should consult with a healthcare provider before attempting Cobra Pose, as the backbend may exacerbate their condition. People with neck issues, including cervical spine problems, should avoid overextending the neck and keep the head in line with the spine to prevent strain. Pregnant individuals, particularly in the later stages of pregnancy, should also be cautious and avoid deep backbends that may place pressure on the abdomen.

name: Camel Pose
precaution: Camel Pose should be practiced with caution by individuals who have specific back or neck issues, including herniated discs, scoliosis, or hyperextension of the spine. Those with a history of shoulder, knee, or hip injuries should also approach this pose carefully, as it requires significant flexibility and strength in these areas. Individuals with high blood pressure or heart conditions may need to avoid deep backbends or modify the pose to avoid strain. Pregnant individuals should refrain from performing Camel Pose, as it may compress the abdomen. Additionally, people with vertigo or balance issues should take extra care, as the pose involves tilting the head back. Always focus on maintaining a safe and aligned posture and avoid overextending the back to reduce the risk of injury.

name: Bridge Pose
precaution: Those with neck, back, or shoulder injuries should avoid the pose or perform it with modifications to prevent strain on the spine and upper body. People with sacral or lumbar spine issues should be mindful of how they engage their back during the lift, ensuring they don't overextend. Pregnant individuals, particularly in the second and third trimesters, should avoid the pose or consult with a healthcare provider before practicing it, as the position may put unnecessary pressure on the abdomen. Additionally, individuals with knee injuries should be careful when pressing the feet into the floor, as the angle of the knees can exacerbate discomfort. It’s important to maintain proper alignment to avoid strain, especially on the lower back, and to avoid forcing the hips too high or overly arching the spine.

name: Locust Pose
precaution: Those with back or spine issues, such as herniated discs, sciatica, or chronic lower back pain, should avoid or modify the pose to prevent strain on the spine and surrounding muscles. Pregnant individuals should also avoid this pose, as the pressure it places on the abdomen and lower back may be uncomfortable or unsafe. People with neck problems should be mindful of their neck alignment during the pose, as lifting the chest and legs off the floor can put strain on the cervical spine if not properly supported. Additionally, individuals with shoulder injuries or instability should be cautious when lifting the arms and chest, as the pose requires strength and mobility in the shoulders.

name: Half Pigeon Pose
precaution: Practitioners with knee, hip, or lower back issues should avoid or modify the pose to prevent strain. For those with knee pain, it’s essential to keep the knee in alignment and avoid overstretching, as excessive pressure can exacerbate discomfort. People with tight hips or limited flexibility should take care not to force the pose, as pushing too deeply into the stretch can lead to strain in the hip joint or lower back. It’s also important to maintain proper alignment throughout the pose, ensuring the pelvis stays square and the back leg is extended fully, as improper alignment can cause unnecessary stress on the lower back or knees. Individuals with sciatica or herniated discs should consult a healthcare provider before practicing this pose to ensure it is safe for their specific condition.

name: Boat Pose
precaution: Those with lower back issues, such as herniated discs or chronic pain, should be careful, as the pose requires a strong engagement of the core and spine, which could exacerbate discomfort if not performed with proper alignment. Pregnant individuals should avoid the pose in later stages of pregnancy due to the strain it may place on the abdomen and lower back, but can opt for modified versions, such as keeping the legs bent. People with neck problems should also avoid straining the neck by keeping the spine neutral and avoiding excessive chin tucking during the pose.

name: Plow Pose
precaution: Individuals with neck, shoulder, or back issues should approach the pose with caution, as the deep stretch and weight-bearing on these areas can exacerbate existing conditions. To protect the neck, ensure that the weight is distributed across the shoulders and upper back rather than pressing into the cervical spine. Using a folded blanket under the shoulders can create additional support and reduce strain on the neck. Avoid turning the head while in the pose, as this can compromise spinal alignment. Those with high blood pressure, glaucoma, or other eye and ear conditions should consult with a healthcare professional before attempting Halasana, as the inversion may increase pressure in these areas. Pregnant individuals and those with conditions like herniated discs, sciatica, or osteoporosis should also avoid the pose unless guided by an experienced instructor.

name: Dancer Pose
precaution: Those with a history of ankle, knee, or hip injuries should be especially careful, as the posture requires significant balance and engagement of the lower body. People with back issues, particularly in the lower back or spine, should avoid deep backbends or seek modifications to prevent strain. Additionally, those with shoulder injuries may find the arm extension in Dancer Pose challenging, as it requires opening the chest and reaching the arm forward while stabilizing the back. Pregnant individuals, especially in the later stages, may want to avoid the intense backbend or deep stretch in this pose, opting for a gentler variation. It’s also important for beginners to approach Dancer Pose gradually, ensuring proper alignment and avoiding overstretching, as falling or straining in the pose can lead to injury.

name: Bow Pose
precaution: Those with existing back injuries, chronic lower back pain, or spinal conditions such as herniated discs should avoid this pose or practice it under the guidance of a qualified instructor. Similarly, individuals with recent abdominal surgeries or conditions like ulcers, hernias, or severe digestive issues should refrain from practicing Bow Pose, as the intense abdominal stretch may exacerbate these conditions. Pregnant individuals should also avoid this posture, as it compresses the abdomen. Additionally, those with shoulder or neck injuries, high blood pressure, or migraines should exercise care or modify the pose to suit their needs.

name: Wheel Pose
precaution: Those with back or spinal issues, such as herniated discs, scoliosis, or sacral instability, should be particularly cautious, as the deep backbend can exacerbate these conditions. Individuals with neck or shoulder injuries may also be at risk due to the significant strain placed on these areas during the pose. Those with limited flexibility in the shoulders, hips, or wrists should take care, as these areas are heavily engaged in maintaining the posture. People with high blood pressure or heart conditions should also be mindful, as the inversion and lifting of the chest can increase circulation to the upper body. Additionally, pregnant individuals, especially in later stages, should avoid Wheel Pose due to the pressure it places on the abdomen. As a physically demanding pose, Wheel Pose requires proper alignment and strength, so individuals new to yoga or those with limited flexibility should be cautious when attempting it.
